page.title: 03CROFTING ON WHALSAY
page.content: On our island there are over 80 crofts but most are quite small.Few people are full-time crofters,few cattle are kept,only a handful of milking cows.In the past 15 years the number of sheep kept has fallen from just under 2000 to under 700. Crofting is obviously not so important to families as once was. Crops grown include hay,corn,potatoes and kale-Shetland long stalked cabbage ,all grown mostly for animal feed. The northerly situation of our island means that spring is late coming, summer is short but because of the long days crops grow quickly. Lambing starts in April,a typical croft keeping about 27 ewes,producing 34-40 lambs of which 30 or so are sold at the yearly sale held in September. Use is made of the nearby islets for grazing during summer.
